decision_conditions: Where an advertisement is required under these Regulations to be removed, the site shall be left in a condition that does not endanger the public or impair visual amenity.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 and in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Any structure or hoarding erected or used principally for the purpose of displaying advertisements shall be maintained in a condition that does not endanger the public.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 and in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Any advertisement displayed, and any site used for the display of advertisements, shall be maintained in a condition that does not impair the visual amenity.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 and in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No advertisement to be displayed without the permission of the owner of the site or any other person with an interest in the site entitled to grant permission.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007.

No advertisement shall be sited or displayed so as to - (a) endanger persons using any highway, railway, waterway, dock, harbour or aerodrome (civil or military);(b) obscure, or hinder the ready interpretation of, any traffic sign, railway signal or aid to navigation by water or air; or (c) Hinder the operation of any device used for the purpose of security or surveillance or for measuring the speed of any vehicle. Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007.

The intensity of the illumination of the lighting permitted by this consent shall be no greater than 400 cd/m.Reason: In the interests of amenity, the free flow of traffic on the highway and road safety in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises a semi detached dwelling located to the east of Dysart Avenue, Kingston Upon Thames.The site is not subject to any land use designations. 7 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1 letter of support was received. Planning HistoryAny relevant planning history for the site has been taken into account in considering this application and recent planning history is available to view on the Council's website.The key areas of assessment are: - Design and character - Neighbour amenity  Design and CharacterPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposal is for a single storey rear extension measuring 5m in depth and extending the full width of the existing dwelling. The extension has a pitched roof (with PV panels atop) ranging in height between 2.95m and 3.9m.The proposed extension is appropriate in design and materials and proportionate in scale to the main dwelling. For these reasons, the proposal is not considered to result in harm to the character and appearance of the area and is therefore in accordance with Policy D3 of the London Plan (2021) and Policies CS8 and DM 10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and Residential Design Guide SPD (2013).AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment:The proposed extension extends approximately 2m beyond the neighbouring No. 15 Dysart Avenue (which has an existing rear extension). The plans indicate that the proposed extension would not interrupt the 45 degree line (on plan). On this basis, and given the height is not unreasonable, the proposal is not considered overbearing or likely to result in an undue loss of daylight and sunlight to this neighbour. The proposal is not considered to result in an undue loss of privacy for this neighbour. With regard to No. 11 Dysart Avenue, there is a significant separation of approximately 4m to this neighbour. On this basis, and as the height and depth is not unreasonable and as the proposal would not interrupt the 45 degree line to the nearest habitable windows, the proposal is not considered overbearing or likely to result in an undue loss of daylight and sunlight to this neighbour. The proposal is not considered to result in an undue loss of privacy for this neighbour.For these reasons, the proposed extension is not considered to result in an undue loss of amenity for surrounding neighbours, in accordance with Policy DM10 of the RBK Core Strategy (2012).Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has submitted a brief Fire Safety Strategy which covers the crtieria set out in Policy D12(A) for a development of this scale and nature and can be secured by way of condition. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.Overall the development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and as such, planning permission is recommended for approval, subject to the conditions listed above.

Application SiteThe site comprises a tennis club.ProposalInstallation of 10 nos led lighting to two central tennis courtsConsultation26 Neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.RBK Environmental Health Officer - No ObjectionsRBK Biodiversity Officer - Raised concerns regarding Bat foraging times between October and November. However, it is noted that the adjoining site, Surbiton Racket Club has permission to allow lighting at these times also.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Impact on batsDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed lighting would be installed away from the road and would not be readily visible within the streetscene. For this reason, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  The proposed courts would be sited a significant distance away from the nearest neighbouring residential property and the noise associated with them would not amount to anything over and above that generated by the existing use of the site. The application is supported by a lighting report which demonstrates that there would be minimal light spill from the proposed floodlights beyond the site boundaries. Officers recommend that the illuminance levels of the lighting be controlled by condition and subject to this condition, officers are satisfied that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Impact on BatsAs is noted in the Consultations section above, the Biodiversity Officer raised some concerns over the hours of illumination and how this could impact when Bats forage between October and November. However, noting that there are no equivalent restrictions at the neighbouring site which has a relatively recent planning permission for a similar form of development, Officers do not consider it would be reasonable to apply a condition restricting hours of illumination in October and November beyond what the applicant has stated in their submission.  On balance, it is considered that the potential impact on foraging bats in the vicinity would be acceptable when compared to the existing situation.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a residential dwelling.ConsultationNo response received. AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Other mattersDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Paragraphs 194 - 202 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage or non designated asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development or cause any harm to the non designated heritage asset the Cleaveland Road/The Mall Local Area of Special Character.  Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Other mattersA condtion securing a fire safety strategy is recommended to ensure the development is fire safe in accordance with policy D12 of the London Plan. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

Application SiteThe site is occupied by a two storey detached dwelling, and is a corner site located on the southern side of Lawrence Avenue where it intersects with Landseer Road.The site is not subject to any land use designations or environmental constraints.ProposalThe proposal seeks to vary the approved plans of planning permission 22/00186/HOU for the Demolition of existing rear conservatory, erection of front porch, part two storey part single storey infill to side and rear extension with juliet balcony in first floor. Erection of roof extension with 1no rear and 2nos side dormers, installation of 3 nos front, 2 nos side  roof light to facilitate loft conversion. Formation of dropped kerb. The application seeks the following: Amendments to the approved single storey rear extension to reduce the depth from 8m to 6m (near the common boundary with No. 28 Lawrence Avenue and increase the width by an additional 3.45m to span the full width of the dwelling (as extended). In addition, alterations to the fenestration to the north west facing flank have been altered to include a greater degree of glazing and a juliet balcony is now prepared to the second floor rear elevation. Originally full height openings and juliet balconies were proposed to the first floor rear , however, during the course of this application, amended plans have been received omitting these proposals. Consultation6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals. No representations have been received. AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire safetyDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: In the context of approved application 22/00186/HOU, the proposed changes are considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  Although the previously approved application was considered acceptable (having regard to the established fallback position), the proposed scheme would only offer an improvement on the living conditions of the occupiers as the depth of the extension would be reduced by 2m.  No adverse impacts are expected from the increased glazing to the ground floor north-west facing elevation or the juliet balcony at seconfd floor level. In conclusion, It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The application seeks approval the details required by Conditions 5 (Programme for part 4 of the Preliminary Ecological Appraisal Survey) and 6 (External Lighting) of Planning Permission 20/01702/FUL.Condition 5 states:No above ground works shall commence until a detailed programme setting out the timeframe for the implementation of the recommendations set out within part 4 of the submitted Preliminary Ecological Appraisal Survey by Arbtech dated 29.01.2021 has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved programme and a qualified Ecological Clerk of Works shall over see the works. Reason: To safeguard the biodiversity and nature conservation value of the site, in accordance with policy G6 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS3 and DM6 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Assessment: An Ecological Enhancement and Management Plan, prepared by  suitably qualified ecological consultancy, has been submitted which sets out ecological mitigation measures during the construction works including to prevent pollution, dust and to ensure that any necessary external lighting complies with Bat Conservation Trust compliant guidelines. The Ecological Enhancement and Management Plan also includes a programme of works (including timing of implementation) for the enhancements set out in the Preliminary Ecological Appraisal which includes the establishment of a relaxed mowing regime, creation of invertebrate and reptile friendly mosaic of scrub, bare ground, wildflower meadow, pollinator plantings, installation of a green roof, planting of fruit trees and the creation of a wildlife pond. The details submitted are considered sufficient to discharge this condition. Conclusion: The details have been reviewed and officers are satisfied that submitted details meet the requirements for Condition 5 of Planning Permission 20/01702/FUL.

The application seeks approval the details required by Condition 6 (External Lighting) of Planning Permission 20/01702/FUL.Condition 6 states:Any external lighting installed at the site shall only be installed in accordance with a scheme which has previously been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. Any scheme shall address the biodiveristy interests of the site in particular, but not limited to, Bats. Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, and to safeguard the bio diversity and nature conservation value of the site, in accordance with policy G6 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS3 and DM6 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012 and policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Assessment: Details of the 2 security lights proposed to the front of the building have been provided. These are LED lights and come in a warm colour (3,000 kelvins) which aligns with Bat Conservation Trust guidelines. Given the scale and nature of the proposal and external lighting, these details are considered acceptable. Conclusion: The details have been reviewed and officers are satisfied that submitted details meet the requirements for Condition 6 of Planning Permission 20/01702/FUL.
